description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut om stöd till UNICEF för projektet "Improving Maternal, Newborn and Child Health through Integrated Approaches" i West Nile 2017-2018. Beslutet tas i enlighet med Sidas insatshanteringsregel, paragraf 3.11.3.
UNICEF har den 23 november 2016 inkommit med en ansökan till Sida för ovan nämnda program med en initial budget på 35 MSEK för 2017-2018. Det föreslagna stödet till UNICEF syftar till att bidra till minskad mödra, neonatal och barnadödlighet samt förbättrad barnhälsa och utveckling i West Nile regionen, genom att stärka hälso- och sjukvårdssektorns kapacitet att tillhandahållanda mödra- och barnhälsovård av god kvalitet med fokus på integrerade och innovativa strategier. Projektets primära målgrupp är gravida kvinnor, nyblivna mödrar, nyfödda barn och barn under fem år i åtta distrikt i West Nile - en region som mottagit ett stort antal sydsudanesiska flyktingar.
West Nile regionen har några av de lägsta hälsoindikatorerna i Uganda, t.ex. antal vaccinerade barn, antal födslar på kliniker och användning av myggnät, med hög förekomst av malaria, diarré och hiv/aids. Regionen har en av de högsta nivåerna av barnadödlighet, där uppskattningsvis 125 barn dör innan de uppnått fem års åldern per 1000 levande födda barn, jämfört med Ugandas genomsnitt på 90. Sedan december 2013 har regionen sett en stor ökning av flyktingar från Sydsudan, vilket ansträngt den redan otillräckliga hälssosektorn ytterligare. Sedan konflikten intensifierades i juli i år har antalet flytkingar uppgått till över 30 000 per månad. För närvarande befinner sig över 500 000 sydsudanesiska flyktingar i West Nile regionen, varav cirka 86 procent är kvinnor och barn.
UNICEF arbetar både med utvecklings- och humanitärt bistånd och är en av UNHCR:s och regeringens viktigaste partners i flyktingmottagandet, med fokus på livräddande åtgärder inom hälsa, nutrition, vatten, sanitet och hygien. Sveriges nuvarande resultatstrategi för Uganda fokuserar inte på att stärka länken mellan utvecklingsstöd och humanitärt bistånd, katastrofriskreducering (DRR) eller resiliens. Det föreslagna stödet till UNICEF syftar därför till att stärka kapaciteten inom hälsosektorn i West Nile samt möta upp det ökade behovet av hälso- och sjukvårdstjänster och den humanitära responsen i de distrikt som mottar störst andel flyktingar. Genom att stödja UNICEF:s reguljära verksamhet i West Nile kan UNICEF även frigöra medel för sin humanitära verksamhet, idag allvarligt underfinansierad.
Support to maternal and child health in Karamoja.

The development intervention's intended outcome is to contribute to the reduction of maternal and new-born morbidity and mortality in Karamoja region by increasing access to an integrated comprehensive package of quality maternal, new-born and child health and nutrition services that strengthens the continuum of care from the community to the health facility holistically.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Summary of key results The analysis below is based on the summary of results in the final narrative report. For more detailed results, please see attached full report. Outcome 1: Strengthened capacity of district health management teams (DHMTs) to plan, implement, coordinate, monitor, and evaluate priority maternal and new-born survival interventionsAll seven districts in Karamoja have improved their capacity to generate and utilize data for planning and decision making with variations in capacity at district level (100 per cent of target). This improvement is attributed to the Health Systems Strengthening (HSS) approach that focused on strengthening districts’ capacity in evidence-based planning and budgeting using the Ministry of Health (MoH) planning guidelines, the Reproductive Maternal Newborn Child Adolescent Health - RMNCAH scorecard and bottleneck and causality analysis. Outcome 2: Increased availability of Essential Maternal Newborn Child Health services (New-born Care, Ante Natal Care, Deliveries, Post Natal Care) at the facility levels.A total of 78 (5 Hospitals, 4 HCIVs, 43 HCIIIs and 26 high volume HCIIIs) out of the 125 health facilities in Karamoja provided holistic and integrated RMNCAH services (62 per cent), which exceeds the programme target of 50 per cent of health facilities. The target of reaching 50 per cent of overall facilities was set based on the low coverage of services in Karamoja and significant requirements for investment in each health facility to ensure the provision of integrated RMNCAH services. Significant gains were made in improving availability of quality services. UNICEF, with SIDA funds, provided substantial support in terms of training, procurement of equipment and supplies, and salary support for medical officers at HCIVs. As a result, all designated Comprehensive Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care (CEmONC) facilities were functional in 2016 with 4/4 HCIVs and 5/5 Hospitals providing CEmONC services where 43/43 HCIIIs are providing BEmONC service with all signal functions except assisted vaginal deliveries which require supervision of a medical doctor. Outcome 3: Increased accessibility and utilization of Minimum Integrated Comprehensive (MIC) package for Health and Nutrition, including nutrition, MCH, HIV/AIDS and WASH services.There was improved access and utilization of the services for maternal and newborn care in Karamoja. The proportion of mothers attending more than one antenatal care visit (ANC 1) increased from 55 per cent in 2015 to 83 per cent in 2017, against a target of 60 per cent. The proportion of mothers attending more than four ANC visits (ANC 4) increased from 37 to 38 per cent, while women delivering in health facilities increased from 38 to 52 per cent in the same period. The postnatal check-up rate within one day after delivery increased from 38 to 44 per cent from 2015 to 2017. This is an indication of improved continuum of care from pregnancy, during and after delivery. To increase service coverage, UNICEF strengthened existing community platforms such as Village Health Teams (VHTs) and peer mother’s groups. VHTs mapped pregnant women in their villages in order to link them to health facilities. In addition, the VHTs visited 63% of mothers/newborns who delivered in health facilities within the first week of delivery so that mothers/newborns with danger signs could be identified in timely manner for referral to health facilities. The peer mother groups contributed to increasing awareness on maternal and newborn health (MNH) care and as a result, 7,200 women were sensitized on birth preparedness and essential MNH care through the groups. Despite these investments, Karamoja remains one of the most disadvantaged regions in Uganda where the population suffers from multiple deprivations, resulting in high mortality rates for women and children. Sustainability of interventions in this region depends on many interrelated factors such as the ability of the Government to increase its support to the region. This includes support to infrastructural development, human resources for health, and continuous behavioural change. To maximize health gains, there is also a need to increase involvement from other sectors, and to improve livelihood opportunities and youth engagement in the region.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
